title: Potential and power - cart on ramp and consv force

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A cart is located on a straight ramp, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Initially, a string parallel to the ramp holds the cart in place.

(a) The dot in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> represents the cart when it is held in place on the ramp by the string, and the gridlines in the figure are oriented parallel and perpendicular to the ramp. On the dot, draw and label the forces (not components) exerted on the cart. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot. The relative lengths of the arrows should indicate the relative magnitudes of the forces, and the vector sum of the arrows should indicate the correct direction, if any, of the net force on the cart. The force <math alttext="F sub N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>N</mi></msub></math> exerted on the cart by the ramp is already drawn on the figure.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A cart is located on a straight ramp, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Initially, a string parallel to the ramp holds the cart in place.

(a) The dot in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> represents the cart when it is held in place on the ramp by the string, and the gridlines in the figure are oriented parallel and perpendicular to the ramp. On the dot, draw and label the forces (not components) exerted on the cart. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot. The relative lengths of the arrows should indicate the relative magnitudes of the forces, and the vector sum of the arrows should indicate the correct direction, if any, of the net force on the cart. The force <math alttext="F sub N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>N</mi></msub></math> exerted on the cart by the ramp is already drawn on the figure.

The string holding Cart <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is cut, allowing the cart to roll without slipping down the ramp, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. There is negligible friction in the axles of the cart’s wheels, and the rotational inertia of the wheels is negligible. After reaching the bottom of the ramp, which is located at position <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the cart continues to roll along a horizontal surface in the positive <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction. The cart encounters a conservative force <math alttext="F of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> in the region <math alttext="x is greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></math> as follows, where the quantities <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>b</mi></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> are positive constants.
<math alttext="F of x equals, open brace, Line 1: negative b x comma 0 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to x sub 0. Line 2: negative b x sub 0 comma x sub 0 is less than or equal to x, which is less than 2 x sub 0. Line 3: 0 comma x is greater than 2 x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>,</mo></mtd><mtd><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>
(b) For each region given in the equation for <math alttext="F of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, derive an equation for the potential energy <math alttext="U of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>U</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> that results from <math alttext="F of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Take <math alttext="U of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>U</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> to be zero at <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, and express <math alttext="U of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>U</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> in terms of <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>b</mi></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>, <math alttext="x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

Assume that the cart is still moving in the positive <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction when it reaches <math alttext="x equals 3 x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. The axes in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> indicate the region <math alttext="x sub 0 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 3 x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>.
(c) On the axes shown in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the power <math alttext="P of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> delivered to the cart by the conservative force <math alttext="F of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the range <math alttext="x sub 0 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 3 x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>.
Note: Your graph does not need to indicate the correct curvature for <math alttext="P of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, but should indicate the correct sign and whether <math alttext="P of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> is increasing, decreasing, or constant as <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> increases.

(d) Indicate whether the graph you drew in part (c) is consistent with the force <math alttext="F of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> exerted on the cart when it is moving in the positive <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction. Justify your answer, paying attention to the two regions <math alttext="open parenthesis, x sub 0 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 2 x sub 0, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="open parenthesis, 2 x sub 0 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 3 x sub 0, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 1.A: Create diagrams, tables, charts, or schematics to represent physical situations.
